hints.content:
The divergence of a vector field measures how much the vector field expands or contracts in a given region. Expansion means a positive divergence, contraction means a negative divergence, and neither means a zero divergence. We can look at the vectors directly around a point to find its divergence.

[[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation:
The vector field below has negative, positive, and zero divergence in different places.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/0397aba93d80b54f669909b9cceb804032dd2a87)

Around the left point, the vectors have the same $x$-component, but they point down from above and up from below. This squeezing is an example of contraction, which is why the divergence there is negative.

Around the middle point, the vectors all have the same $x$-component, and an equal amount of vectors have positive and negative $y$-components. There's no net squeezing or stretching, which is why the divergence there is zero.

Around the right point, the vectors again have the same $x$-component, but now they point up from above and down from below. This pulling apart is an example of expansion, which is why the divergence there is positive.

question.content:
Here's a vector field:

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/ce168b368e32a0772365541190d0aedbcf5c9094)

**What is the sign of the divergence at the center of the vector field?**

[[☃ radio 1]]
